awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Next Generation of STEM Teacher Preparation in Washington State
awd_abstract_narration:
The Next Generation of STEM Teacher Preparation project is led by five institutions of higher education in Washington State.  This collaborative effort will engage institutions involved in the preparation of teachers of STEM disciplines, Washington State's Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction, P-12 educators, and other key stakeholders from business, government, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), in bringing about statewide sustainable change in the preparation of STEM teachers at all levels.  The project moves away from isolated, single institutional program improvement efforts, to colleges and universities in Washington State working collaboratively to improve STEM teacher preparation in partnership with two-year colleges, P-12 schools, community groups, and businesses. The project will result in the production of more, highly qualified, P-12 science and mathematics teachers, including a new cadre of teachers prepared to teach computer science and engineering. In addition, the project seeks to increase the diversity of the STEM teacher workforce by actively recruiting and incentivizing underrepresented students from STEM majors at 2- and 4-year colleges to become P-12 middle and high school STEM teachers.  Financial support for this project comes from NSF's Improving Undergraduate Education program and the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program.

The project's primary goals are: 
1.	To improve STEM teacher preparation programs in Washington State (impacting greater than 90% of the state's future STEM teacher graduates,
2.	Increase recruitment of qualified and diverse STEM students into teaching, and
3.	Create an adaptive, research-based model for improving STEM teacher preparation through collaboration. 
To achieve these goals, the project will: (a) create a common vision for STEM teacher preparation in Washington State, (b) share, develop, adapt, implement, and evaluate resources and models to achieve this vision, and (c) build and assess a model of continuous, collaborative program improvement. The critical components of teacher preparation this project will address include:  improving pre-service teachers' clinical practice and new teachers' induction experiences, improving the disciplinary and STEM pedagogical content knowledge of pre-service teachers, and integrating computer science, engineering, and sustainability into teacher preparation. Cross-institutional Working Groups dedicated to improving each component will research, create, and produce a set of materials and professional development workshops. Regional Teams of faculty and administrators from institutions of higher education, P-12 educators, and representatives from STEM businesses, NGOs, and government agencies, will in turn adapt these materials and professional development experiences to support and sustain STEM teacher preparation program improvements at their institutions. Three capacity-building components: organizational change, increasing the diversity of the STEM teaching workforce, and collaboration building, will underlie the efforts of every Working Group and Regional Team.

por.por_cntn:
The Next Generation of STEM Teacher Preparation (NGSTP) in Washington State                                                              

In Washington State we have developed a collaborative model for improving the recruitment, preparation, and graduation of future Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) teachers statewide. Instead of competing for students, prestige, and resources, our model promotes collaboration, product development, and expertise sharing across and within institutions for the benefit of all students. Our model is guided by a common vision of the knowledge, skills, and abilities secondary STEM teachers, and elementary teachers of STEM will need to prepare and inspire future scientists, mathematicians, engineers, teachers, and informed citizens. In addition to our common vision, the NGSTP model has three major features: (a) a set of goals and norms that guide the work, (b) knowledge curation and generation (i.e., research and development) by cross-institutional, expert, working groups, and (c) uptake, adaptation, and application of knowledge and products by university-based Implementation Teams to enact improvements at the program, institutional, and state level.

From 2016-2022, faculty, staff, and students from 12 university campuses in Washington State collaborated with experts from K-12 education, community colleges, government agencies, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to: (1) to improve STEM teacher preparation programs in the state (impacting greater than 90% of Washington?s future STEM teacher graduates), (2) increase recruitment of qualified and diverse STEM students into teaching, and (3) create an adaptive, research-based model for improving STEM teacher preparation through collaboration. 

During the past six years, NGSTP has made significant progress toward all these goals.  Outcomes include: (a) A strong multi-institutional collaboration that supports expertise sharing across and within institutions (Higher Ed, K-12, Government, NGO), (b) Alignment of our STEM teacher preparation programs to state and national standards, (c) Creation of new tools and resources, (d) Modification of existing curricula and courses to incorporate research-based practices, enriched content, and new teaching strategies and practices, (e) Development of new teacher endorsement and credential programs in Computer Science, Environmental and Sustainability Education, and elementary Science Engineering and Technology education, and (f) The creation and sharing of recommendations and strategies with state and organizational decision makers to improve the STEM teaching workforce. We have also created a Teacher Endorsement database and associated visualization tools to help identify and understand STEM teacher shortage areas (grades 6-8 and 9-12) across Washington state.  Our products have been disseminated via professional development workshops, at state and national conferences, through publications, and on our Innovations in STEM Teacher Preparation website (see below). Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) research, habits of mind, and effective practices have been infused into all aspects of our work. Several partner institutions have developed and are currently implementing DEI action plans to support the recruitment, preparation, and success of first-generation students and students of color in secondary STEM education majors. 

As evidenced by the outcomes above, and by ongoing work between project partners, we have developed an effective, collaborative model for STEM teacher preparation program improvement. Through collaboration, we have helped to break down traditional silos and barriers between institutions, between colleges of Education and colleges of Arts-Sciences-Engineering, between higher education and K-12 schools, and between individuals. The power of this model is that it allows us to leverage the diversity of ideas, perspectives, and expertise that exist across an entire state instead of in only one institution or one region. Our NGSTP model is also flexible and dynamic as it allows participants to work toward a shared vision but supports individual program improvement priorities.  In addition, by leveraging the collective expertise and resources of multiple programs and institutions, we can speak with a more powerful, unified voice in support of STEM teaching and STEM workforce improvements. Finally, while our model is focused on improving STEM teaching, we believe many NGSTP model components and processes could be adapted to strategically improve other aspects of K-12 and higher education. 

NGSTP materials can be accessed through the following website:  

https://serc.carleton.edu/stemteacherprep/index.html

For more information, please contact: Ed Geary (WWU-retired) or Emily Borda, Director of Science, Mathematics and Technology Education (SMATE) at Western Washington University

Emails:  egeary17@gmail.com; Emily.Borda@wwu.edu
